sub_subject.name: Worldview, Biblical Geography & Stewardship
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Worldview, Biblical Geography & Stewardship (Geography)

objectives.objective_text: Identify that God owns the world, we just live here.
Name kindness to animals as a good thing.
Identify a neighbor as anyone we meet.
Name being kind to strangers as good.
Identify people as gardeners of the world.
Name taking care of pets and plants as our job.
Identify 'Home' as a special place.
Name where I come from.
Identify the world as something God made good.
Name rocks, trees, and water as God's gifts.
Identify the Jordan River.
Name the 12 Tribes who got land.
Identify the Philistine plain.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Identify Eden as the first garden home.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Name the Tigris and Euphrates rivers.
Identify the Red Sea.
Name the desert where they walked.
Identify Abraham's long trip.
Name Canaan as the Promised Land.
Identify Bethlehem, Nazareth, and Jerusalem.
Name the Sea of Galilee (where Jesus walked on water).
Identify a boat used for travel.
Name Paul as the missionary traveler.
Identify different kinds of animals.
Name Noah as the first person to save animals.
Identify that the world belongs to God.
Name ourselves as God's helpers.
Identify farmers taking care of the soil.
Name forests as places for animals.
Identify sun and wind as things that don't run out.
Name oil and coal as things we dig up.
Identify that we shouldn't take more than we need.
Name sharing as a good way to live.
Identify water as precious.
Name ways we use water (drinking, washing).
Recall that God feeds the birds.
Observe that we should not waste water or food.
Recall the Good Samaritan.
Observe that people from other countries are God's children too.
Recall that we shouldn't ruin God's world.
Observe that littering is bad stewardship.
Recall that Jesus had a hometown (Nazareth).
Observe that where we live shapes what we do.
Recall that God likes what He made.
Observe beauty in nature.
Recall that the land had milk and honey.
Observe a map with different colored tribes.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Recall that the first people lived near these rivers.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Observe maps showing where Eden might have been.
Recall Mount Sinai as the big mountain.
Observe that deserts are hot and dry.
Recall that they lived in tents and moved around.
Observe the route from Ur to Haran to Canaan.
Recall that Jesus walked everywhere.
Observe the Jordan River where Jesus was baptized.
Recall that the Good News went to the whole world.
Observe lines on a map showing Paul's trips.
Recall that God made every animal special.
Observe that some animals are in danger.
Recall that we should keep the world clean for God.
Observe beauty as a gift from God.
Recall that trees help the earth.
Observe that plants need good dirt.
Recall that we should use things wisely.
Observe solar panels or windmills.
Recall that God gives us everything.
Observe that some people don't have enough.
Recall that we shouldn't make water dirty.
Observe rain catching in a barrel.
Defend access to water as a basic human necessity.
Summarize why we protect nature (because God made it).
Explain that humans are more important than animals (Image of God).
Explain the 'Tragedy of the Commons'.
Defend the priority of human flourishing alongside creation care.
Summarize the command to love the stranger.
Explain what hospitality means (making room for others).
Explain the biblical origin of nations (Babel and Pentecost).
Defend the dignity of every ethnicity and culture.
Summarize the Dominion Mandate (Genesis 1:28).
Explain the difference between 'using' and 'using up'.
Explain the Christian duty to manage resources wisely.
Defend a balanced view of dominion that rejects abuse.
Summarize how geography changes how people live (food, clothes).
Explain that God placed us where we are for a reason.
Explain the concept of 'inculturation' of the Gospel.
Defend the value of local community commitments.
Summarize 'God saw that it was good' (Genesis 1).
Explain that matter (stuff) is not evil.
Explain why we care for the earth.
Defend the goodness of the material world against asceticism.
Summarize the division of the land among the 12 tribes.
Explain the strategic value of Jericho.
Explain the Transjordan tribes (Reuben, Gad, Manasseh).
Defend the geographical logic of Solomon's fortified cities.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Summarize the geography of the Fertile Crescent.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Explain why civilization started between two rivers (Mesopotamia).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Locate modern-day Iraq as the setting for early Genesis.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Explain the environmental conditions that supported early civilization.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Defend the historicity of biblical locations using archaeological data.
Summarize the geography of the Sinai Peninsula.
Explain the miracle of the Red Sea crossing.
Trace the possible route on a map.
Explain the debate over the location of Mt. Sinai (Traditional vs. Arabia).
Defend the historicity of the wilderness wanderings.
Summarize the route of the Patriarchs along the Fertile Crescent.
Explain why they went to Egypt during famines (Nile reliability).
Locate Hebron, Bethel, and Shechem.
Explain the strategic value of the Negev.
Defend the geographical accuracy of the travel narratives in Genesis.
Summarize the three main regions: Galilee, Samaria, Judea.
Explain why Jews avoided Samaria.
Locate the Mount of Olives.
Explain the political geography of Herod's kingdom.
Defend the geographical accuracy of the Gospels (e.g., John's details).
Summarize Paul's three missionary journeys.
Explain how Roman Roads helped spread the Gospel.
Locate Rome, Athens, and Antioch.
Explain the geography of the Seven Churches of Revelation.
Defend the historical reliability of Acts based on geographical details.
Summarize what 'Biodiversity' means (many kinds of life).
Explain why extinction is sad.
Explain the value of ecosystems beyond human use.
Defend the intrinsic value of creation distinct from utility.
Summarize the Christian duty to care for creation.
Explain that we worship the Creator, not the creation.
Explain the mandate to 'tend and keep'.
Defend a hopeful eschatology against nihilistic climate anxiety.
Summarize why soil is important for food.
Explain erosion (wind/water moving dirt).
Explain sustainable forestry practices.
Defend the biblical mandate to 'keep' the garden.
Summarize the difference between renewable and finite resources.
Explain how we use fossil fuels.
Explain the stewardship of the earth's mineral wealth.
Defend the responsible use of non-renewable resources.
Summarize the tension between using land and saving land.
Explain 'Sustainability' (using without using up).
Explain the role of technology in solving resource problems.
Defend the rights of future generations to resources.
Summarize the importance of clean drinking water.
Explain how pollution hurts rivers and oceans.
Explain the water cycle's vulnerability.
Compare Christian care for nature with worshipping nature.
Apply conservation to daily habits.
Analyze the difference between 'Conservation' and 'Preservation'.
Interpret biblical laws regarding land rest and animal care.
Connect environmental degradation to sin and greed.
Compare fear of strangers (Xenophobia) with love of strangers.
Apply global awareness to prayer for the nations.
Analyze the Old Testament laws regarding the 'Sojourner'.
Interpret the Great Commission (make disciples of all nations).
Connect geography to the distribution of unreached people groups.
Compare a good ruler (steward) with a bad ruler (tyrant).
Apply the idea of tending and keeping the earth.
Analyze the concept of Stewardship vs. Exploitation.
Interpret the Fall's impact on the ground (thorns and thistles).
Connect human flourishing to environmental health.
Compare city life with country life in the Bible.
Apply gratitude for our own community.
Analyze how physical environment shapes culture (Environmental Determinism vs Possibilism).
Interpret the connection between land and identity in the OT.
Connect the loss of place (Exile) to spiritual crisis.
Compare a biblical view of nature with a Gnostic view (body is bad).
Apply thankfulness for the physical world.
Analyze the dualism of Gnosticism vs. Biblical Realism.
Interpret Psalm 19 and Psalm 104 (God's glory in nature).
Connect the Incarnation (Jesus becoming flesh) to the value of matter.
Compare the geography of the Northern Kingdom (Israel) and Southern Kingdom (Judah).
Analyze the defensive advantages of Jerusalem's topography (valleys).
Interpret the phrase 'from Dan to Beersheba'.
Connect the tribal allotments to the physical landscape.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Compare the garden of Eden with the Tower of Babel location.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the strategic importance of the Fertile Crescent for trade and war.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Interpret the geographical plausibility of the Flood narrative.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Connect Abraham's journey from Ur to the geography of the region.
Compare the fertile Nile Delta (Goshen) with the Wilderness.
Analyze the logistics of moving a nation through a desert biome.
Interpret the location of Kadesh Barnea.
Connect the topography of Sinai to the giving of the Law.
Compare the hill country (safety) with the plains (war).
Analyze the importance of water wells in the patriarchal narratives.
Interpret the 'Via Maris' (Way of the Sea) trade route.
Connect the topography of Canaan to the nomadic lifestyle.
Compare the rural Galilee with the urban Jerusalem.
Analyze the elevation change from Jerusalem down to Jericho.
Interpret the fishing economy of the Sea of Galilee.
Connect the Decapolis (Gentile region) to Jesus' ministry.
Compare travel by land vs. travel by sea in Acts.
Analyze the shipwreck narrative in Acts 27 (nautical geography).
Interpret the strategic choice of cities (Ephesus, Corinth, Philippi).
Connect the spread of the church to trade routes.
Compare a zoo with the wild.
Apply care for God's creatures.
Analyze the role of keystone species.
Interpret the command to be stewards of the animals.
Connect habitat loss to species decline.
Compare hope for a new earth with fear of the end.
Apply stewardship to daily choices.
Analyze the difference between Stewardship and Radical Environmentalism.
Interpret Romans 8:19-22 (Creation groaning).
Connect environmental care to love for the poor (who suffer most from pollution).
Compare healthy land with desertification.
Apply the idea of crop rotation (giving land a rest).
Analyze the causes of deforestation.
Interpret the Sabbath Year for the land (Leviticus 25).
Connect soil health to human health.
Compare clean energy with dirty energy.
Apply the idea of not wasting electricity.
Analyze the pros and cons of different energy sources.
Interpret the concept of 'Peak Oil'.
Connect energy use to economic development.
Compare conservation (wise use) with preservation (no use).
Apply fairness to how we share water and food.
Analyze the balance between economic growth and environmental protection.
Interpret the 'Tragedy of the Commons'.
Connect resource scarcity to conflict.
Compare water abundance with water scarcity.
Apply water-saving habits at home.
Analyze the global water crisis.
Interpret the 'Water Footprint' of products.
Connect pollution control to loving our neighbor downstream.
Evaluate the secular environmental movement (strengths/weaknesses).
Evaluate current immigration issues through a biblical lens.
Evaluate the Industrial Revolution's impact on the theology of work.
Evaluate the modern feeling of 'placelessness'.
Evaluate the New Age worship of nature vs. Christian stewardship.
Evaluate the impact of topography on the Divided Monarchy's stability.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the relationship between river flooding patterns and theological worldviews.
Evaluate the environmental challenges (water/food) resolved by providence.
Evaluate the agricultural limitations of the Judean hill country.
Evaluate the strategic location of Caesarea Maritima.
Evaluate the physical barriers to the Gospel's spread.
Evaluate the ethics of de-extinction or genetic modification.
Evaluate current climate policies through a Christian lens.
Evaluate the trade-offs of urban sprawl vs. agricultural land.
Evaluate the geopolitical implications of energy transition.
Evaluate the impact of consumerism on resource depletion.
Evaluate the privatization of water resources.
Construct a Christian environmental ethic.
Synthesize Romans 8 (creation groaning) with Christian hope.
Construct a theology of nations and borders (Acts 17:26).
Synthesize global missiology with cultural geography.
Construct an ethic of creation care based on Imago Dei.
Synthesize economic development with environmental responsibility.
Construct an analysis of how geography influences worldview.
Synthesize the Christian identity as 'elect exiles' (1 Peter).
Construct a theological defense of the physical resurrection.
Synthesize the 'New Heavens and New Earth' as a restored physical place.
Construct a strategic analysis of the Conquest campaigns.
Synthesize the relationship between covenant faithfulness and land retention.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Construct a geographical profile of Sumer and Akkad.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Eden, Mesopotamia & the Cradle of Civilization
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the physical geography of Mesopotamia with the biblical narrative.
Construct a comparative analysis of the Northern vs. Southern route theories.
Synthesize the typology of the 'Wilderness' in Scripture.
Construct a map of the geopolitical powers surrounding Canaan in the Bronze Age.
Synthesize the covenant promises with the physical land.
Construct a profile of 1st-Century Judean geography.
Synthesize the physical setting of the Passion Week.
Construct a map of the Pauline mission field.
Synthesize the role of the Pax Romana infrastructure in evangelism.
Construct an argument for species conservation based on God's glory.
Synthesize the psalmists' call for all creation to praise the Lord.
Construct a biblical theology of creation care.
Synthesize the gospel's implications for the physical world.
Construct a plan for preventing soil degradation.
Synthesize land management with food security.
Construct an energy strategy for a sustainable future.
Synthesize the moral imperative to provide energy for the poor.
Construct an ethical framework for resource extraction.
Synthesize biblical wisdom with modern resource management.
Construct a proposal for water conservation in a drought zone.
Synthesize the spiritual symbolism of 'Living Water' with physical thirst.
